PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Ruiz Food Products has worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe working environment.  Compliance Audits, PHA studies, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, in addition to routine PSM/RMP Meetings have generated recommendations to improve safety and compliance at the facility.  These include enhancing employee training policies, revising standard operating procedures, improving documentation and recordkeeping, and updating preventative maintenance policies, as well as ammonia equipment repairs.

Ruiz Food Products, with support from contractors and consultants entrenched in the ammonia refrigeration industry, strives to ensure a safe working environment at the facility for all employees, guests, and visitors.  The facility also plans to improve safety as follows:

An investigation into the facilitys accident history revealed that there have been no significant ammonia releases over the past five years (May 2019  May 2024) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the California state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release at the facility.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the Ruiz Food Products facility and is maintained by the Safety department.  It is based on Cal-OSHAs requirements for Emergency Action Plan (CCR Title 8, Section 3220), as well as EPAs Emergency Response Plan.

Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency response procedures and the evacuation plan.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger, maintenance personnel, and/or their supervisor.  Maintenance personnel will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem.  All employees evacuate to the evacuation assembly areas.  Notifications of response agencies as well the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) is also detailed the Emergency Response policy.  The Ruiz Foods facility also has an established relationship with the local Fire Department who may be called in to assist depending on the scope of an emergency situation.

The Ruiz Food Products ammonia refrigeration system has many safety design features including ammonia leak detectors, microprocessor controlled compressors with automatic safety cutouts, ASME certified pressure vessels, emergency stop controls, and an Emergency Refrigerant Control Box.  In addition, all pressure-rated vessels are equipped with mechanical pressure relief valves that automatically engage in case of a high pressure situation to ensure the integrity of the vessel and associated piping is protected.  Any ammonia that vents from a pressure relief valve is neutralized in the Water Diffusion Tank.

Much of the safety of the refrigeration system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  In addition to routine patrols and inspections at the facility by the security company, the facility has Maintenance / Refrigeration personnel on-site 24/7 who monitor for any abnormal conditions.  The Ruiz Food Products ammonia refrigeration system was designed and constructed in accordance with the recognized industry codes and standards, which specifically detail requirements for safety features.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the system are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to the refrigerant in a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks / unanticipated ammonia odors are noted and repaired immediately.

The RMP responsible personnel (with guidance from contractors and consultants) also routinely review Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP) for the ammonia refrigeration industry to ensure that the facility is properly maintained, and appropriate adjustments are made based on evolving industry standards.

The resulting high pressure ammonia vapor is routed to the condensers (outside), where fans and sprayed water are used to reject latent heat in the ammonia vapor to the atmosphere, causing the ammonia to condense to a high pressure liquid, which drains back into the high pressure vessels.

Multiple auxiliary systems are in place to support the operational and safety requirements of the ammonia refrigeration system including:  ammonia leak detection, pressure relief system w/ water diffusion tank, emergency refrigerant control box, auto purger to remove non-condensible gasses, and a refrigeration control system.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

To deal with the risks involved with ammonia refrigeration, policies and programs have been developed for the Ruiz Food Products facility to limit the risks of an accidental ammonia release and/or minimize the consequences of a significant ammonia release, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.

Policies developed for the PSM and RMP programs include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, standard operating procedures, training, management of change + pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity (inspections / testing / maintenance), hot work permit, contractor management, and incident investigation.  To help coordinate the various elements of the program, a management system has been established that defines responsible parties for the facility to ensure upkeep and implementation of each policy within the RMP and PSM programs.  Compliance Audits are also conducted every 3 years that can identify potential gaps in compliance and recommend actions to achieve full compliance.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Ruiz Food Products facility is located at 501 South Alta Avenue, in Dinuba, California, and opened in the early 1990s as a food manufacturing plant.  The facility is located southwest of downtown Dinuba.  The area to the northeast of the facility is urban with a mixture of commercial and residential zones, and the land to the southwest of the facility is mostly rural farmland.

The regulated substance onsite at Ruiz Food Products is anhydrous ammonia with a maximum intended inventory of approximately 75,000 pounds.   The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed-loop cycle with no planned or anticipated emissions of ammonia, and is used for refrigeration associated with the production and cold storage of Mexican food products.

The accidental release prevention program starts with good operating and manufacturing practices.  All ammonia process equipment, piping, and valves are inspected and maintained on a regular schedule in accordance with manufacturer and industry recommendations.

Refrigeration process equipment at the plant operates continuously based on operational + temperature demands.  One machinery room + refrigeration annex (outdoor) equipment area house the primary equipment including compressors, recirculator packages, accumulator vessels, and auxiliary components, while the condensers are located outside the machinery room.  The evaporators, freezers, and chillers are located throughout the facility at / near each refrigerated zone (independently temperature controlled).

Ammonia is used as the primary refrigerant, which means it is used as a vehicle to move heat from product, secondary coolants (glycol), and cold storage rooms to the outside

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Ruiz Food Products, Inc. recognizes the companys responsibility in ensuring the safety of the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration system at the Ruiz Food Products facility in Dinuba, California.

It is the policy of Ruiz Food Products to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  To accomplish the companys goal in minimizing accidental losses, the company has established safety programs that enable facility personnel to: maximize safety performance, reduce risks of handling ammonia and other potentially hazardous substances, and prepare facility personnel to address emergency situations as they might arise.

Ruiz Food Products draws from several sources and decades of experience + expertise to ensure that the appropriate mitigation measures have been identified and are implemented.  Internal facility personnel with decades of collective experience, the resources of a professional refrigeration contractor, in addition to external risk management consultants all provide guidance to limit the risks of handling ammonia.  The commitment to safety shows in the minimal accident history at the facility.
